repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan National Solidarity Project -
            Promoting community-based development

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on National
            Solidarity Project in Afghanistan. A quarter century of war
            and civil strife in the country seriously damaged rural
            infrastructure and fractured local communities. National
            Solidarity Program elected village-level community
            Development Councils in which women played a key role, to
            implement priority sub projects. As a result, the villages
            have schools for both boys and girls, electricity for the
            homes, and clean drinking water for all.

TF054368-JSDF-AFGHANISTAN: NATIONAL
            SOLIDARITY PROJECT (BANK-EX TF),TF053939-ARTF-NATIONAL SOLIDARITY PROJECT,TF054367-JSDF-AFGHANISTAN: NATIONAL
            SOLIDARITY PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            supporting state-building and development in Afghanistan. In
            late 2001, after the fall of the Taliban and almost three
            decades of conflict, Afghanistan faced a daunting set of
            challenges. World Bank programs were aligned with and in
            support of the National Priority Programs, identified by the
            Afghan Government as key to the development of Afghanistan
            and the transition process. Afghanistan had made remarkable
            progress in many areas. Important development results had
            been achieved in areas such as health, education,
            microfinance, irrigation and rural livelihoods, as well as
            in public financial management. The results achieved reflect
            the massive support of the international community to help
            rebuild Afghanistan and the efforts and ingenuity of many
            enterprising Afghans who continue to deliver services in
            challenging circumstances.

25462228.trustfund:
TF054368-JSDF-AFGHANISTAN: NATIONAL
            SOLIDARITY PROJECT (BANK-EX TF),TF053939-ARTF-NATIONAL SOLIDARITY PROJECT,TF054367-JSDF-AFGHANISTAN: NATIONAL
            SOLIDARITY PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency National
            Solidarity Project for Afghanistan were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: that in a difficult post-conflict situation
            characterized by limited government capacity, the
            project's choice of institutional arrangements
            featuring performance based contracting of service providers
            for management assistance and field implementation lends
            itself to a rapid scaling up of project outreach. The
            challenge of maintaining engineering quality of
            sub-projects, which has been and remains an issue in the
            project and nationally across other projects and programs,
            needs to be managed. However, this can not be effectively
            addressed at the level of a project implementing agency, but
            requires a broader effort aimed at building capacity for
            small and medium contractors coupled with a certification
            process to establish a list of pre-qualified contractors.
            Monitoring and evaluation needs to be strengthened in
            several areas including: (a) entry of baseline data into the
            Management Information System (MIS); (b) periodic audits of
            Community Development Council (CDC) financial management and
            procurement; (c) assessments of livelihoods activities in
            terms of sustainable income increases; (d) entry into the
            MIS and analysis of data on CDC composition to enable an
            assessment of the governance outputs of National Solidarity
            Project (NSP) in terms of inclusiveness versus elite
            capture; (e) assessment of the factors that critically
            influence the functioning and roles of CDCs; and (f)
            assessment of the poverty reduction impacts of the NSP.

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Emergency National solidarity
            Project - Additional  Grant Financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency National Solidarity
            Project (NSP) constitutes the backbone of the
            Government's National Solidarity Program (NSP), co
            financed by several donors through the Bank managed
            Afghanistan Reconstruction Trust Fund. This additional
            financing would provide funds needed to scale-up activities
            under a successful emergency program in the social sector
            that has exceeded the original implementation (including
            disbursement) expectations. The funds to be added through
            this additional grant were not available under IDA 13 in
            June 2005. The scaled up activities are expected to be
            implemented by the original closing date, and are within the
            original project objectives, subject to the same
            implementation arrangements. The additional financing will
            require an amendment to the Development Grant Agreement to
            increase the amount of Block Grants category by US$24.4
            million, Consultants Services, facilitation and training by
            US$15.0 million, Goods by 0.5 million, and Incremental
            Operating Costs by 0.1 million. It is expected the
            additional financing will further community-led
            reconstruction and development of rural infrastructure.
            Approximately 70 percent of program funds return to local
            labor, and virtually all of the benefits from the physical
            works accrue to primary producers. Sub-project choices by
            villagers include physical infrastructure, direct asset
            transfers (e.g. tools and equipment for income generation
            activities) for vulnerable women and disabled people, and
            the use of block grants for income generation activities.
            While premature to estimate economic and financial benefits
            in the current Afghanistan disrupted environment, NSP data
            are being collected however, to enable an estimate of
            expected returns on individual subproject investments. This
            additional grant faces the same implementation risks as the
            overall program, and specific risk and mitigation measures
            that currently apply to NSP remain pertinent.

Afghanistan - Emergency National solidarity

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Emergency National Solidarity
            Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed additional grant for the
            Emergency National Solidarity Project for Afghanistan will
            provide bridge financing for a well-implemented,
            significantly scaled up national priority program, and it
            will enable maintaining the momentum of program
            implementation in the coming months prior to the
            finalization of funding allocation under the
            Government's Solar Year (SY) 1384. The grant will cover
            the funding requirements for block grants to rural
            communities over the last two months of the second year work program.

docna.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Emergency National Solidarity
            Project : additional financing
